root: ^You crawl slowly out of bed. You remember that you need to look for a job today. But first, breakfast.
^As you crawl comfortably out of bed, you think you hear your uncle in the kitchen.
^You navigate down the hallway, and find him turning the pages of a newspaper.
^Mornin', sunshine. Take a seat, I'll fix you up somethin'.
^You know you don't have to, right?

c-2: ^Yeah, don't worry. You can cook me somethin' tomorrow.

Morning201: ^Anyway, what'll it be? Eggs and sausage? Oatmeal and berries? Or just some cereal?
Morning202: ^Good idea. I'll have what you're havin'.
^After some time, Uncle Scott serves the food to each of you as he takes his seat. He takes a sip of coffee.
^Just then, your phone rings. Caller ID speaks the name: Ren. You pick up and answer:
Morning203: ^Hey, you! Did I catch you at a bad time?

c-0: ^Well, I know you wanted to apply to some places today, so I wanted to just wish you good luck!
c-1: ^Well, I know you wanted to apply to some places today, so I wanted to just wish you good luck!
c-2: ^We can talk later if you want, but I just wanted to wish you good luck real quick!

Morning404: ^If you wanted to go for Lilymist Hotel, they're hiring a Pool Receptionist. I don't know if they're "actively hiring", but they seemed interested. Could be pretty fun, not to mention prestigious. You'll apply online for that one.

c-0: ^After talking to my friend Sandra, I know for a fact the Greenmoss Nursery is hiring a Nursery Assistant. Lots of outdoor work. They're hiring anyone apparently. Their application is online, too.
^Guh, the Crumble Café would be such a cool place to work, too. Seems like it's so difficult to get in, but I feel like the owner is pretty open. No harm in applying. Also online, I think.
^And, yeah. That's all I've got. Did you need me to repeat any of that?

Morning405: ^Okay, well good luck! I'll come over later before we go to the River House tonight.
Morning406: ^Oh! I'm so sorry, I forgot to tell you. My mom is throwing a welcome home party for me, and she wants you to come and be welcomed too!
^The River House is the diner my mom runs. I'm making sure you're coming. See you later,
ApplicationSegment201: ^You get off the phone with Ren, and clean your dishes in the sink. Today is the day you've decided to start applying to jobs.
^Ren mentioned that each of the potential jobs had a description on their company website. You get on your computer and decide to look them up.

b: ^Learn more about the Lilymist Hotel job.

c-0: ^You go to the Lilymist Hotel's website, and navigate to the Careers page. You click the "Pool Receptionist" job to get a detailed description.

^"Attend to customer's basic needs in our pool & recreational area, such as but not limited to: renting towels, giving directions, assisting with lost items, checking guests into the pool area. Identify and resolve customer issues. Transfer issues to supervisor when necessary. Organization and people skills are a plus."

b: ^Finish your job search for the day.
^Learn more about the Greenmoss Nursery job.

c-0: ^You go to the Greenmoss Nursery's website, and navigate to a section labeled "Work With Us." You click the "Nursery Assistant" job.

^"Our assistants are primarily responsible for the upkeep of our outdoor displays, including our botanical gardens. Assistants will also help with stocking and merchandising of our indoor gardening store. Prior experience is a plus but not required.
^"Must have strong interpersonal skills, and a passion for the outdoors."

b: ^Finish your job search for the day.
^Learn more about the Crumble Café job.

c-0: ^You go to the Crumble Café's website. It takes a long time, but you find a "Jobs" section. You click a job you feel you would be qualified for: "Bakery Staff."

^"In this role, you will help make breads, pastries, and desserts in our kitchen under reasonable supervision. Must be comfortable working with food and using multiple types of ovens. All food and recipe training will be on-site. No experience necessary. Positive attitude and a love for the Crumble Café is a plus."

b: ^Finish your job search for the day.
^Finish your job search for the day.

ApplicationSegment203a: ^You begin to fill out the application, inputting basic things like your name, your address, and your availability. You declare yourself as available as possible.
^There's a question on the application that sticks out to you, in which you must type your answer: "Are you visually impaired and require reasonable accommodation to perform job duties?"

c-0: ^You put down "Yes" in the answer box.
c-1: ^You put down "None of your business" in the answer box.
c-2: ^You put down "No" in the answer box.

ApplicationSegment204a: ^The application now looks complete. You send it in, hoping for the best.
ApplicationSegment203b: ^You begin to fill out the application, inputting basic things like your name, your address, and your availability. You declare yourself as available as possible.
^Strangely, you couldn't find any extra questions on the application.

c-0: ^The application now looks complete. You send it in, hoping for the best.

ApplicationSegment203c: ^You begin to fill out the application, inputting basic things like your name, your address, and your availability. You declare yourself as available as possible.
ApplicationSegment204c: ^There's a question on the application that sticks out to you, in which you must type your answer: "If you were a loaf of bread, which would you be and why?"

c-0: ^You put down "Sourdough" in the answer box, and manage to give a reason for it, despite the strange question.
c-1: ^You put down "Wheat" in the answer box, and manage to give a reason for it, despite the strange question.
c-2: ^You put down "White" in the answer box, and manage to give a reason for it, despite the strange question.

ApplicationSegment205c: ^The application now looks complete. You send it in, hoping for the best.
ApplicationSegment206: ^You leave your computer, proud of the work you did. You take a deep breath. Applying can take a lot of energy out of you.
RiverHouse201: ^You take an afternoon nap on the couch while Aunt Tilly watches a knitting show, meticulously following along with a creation of her own. Aware of the party at the River House Café tonight, Aunt Tilly nudges you when it's time to go. The two of you briefly get ready, and head off by car.
RiverHouse202: ^Upon parking, you can already hear the sound of classic oldies rock 'n' roll music from outside. You leave the truck and touch your foot down onto a gravel lot. You take Aunt Tilly's arm as the two of you enter the diner. The sound of 50s and 60s music surrounds you.
RiverHouse203: ^You and your Aunt are immediately recognized. You hear a middle-aged woman call out to you:
^Oh hi, Tilly! And you must be
^. Lovely to meet you. Come on in, guys! Pull up a seat at the counter here
^Hi Jeanette! Tell me how things have been.
RiverHouse204: ^Oh, you know. Lettin' trouble in, keepin' trouble out. That sort of thing.

^You don't understand the expression completely, but you say hi, and sit at a rotating seat at the bar counter with your Aunt. Suddenly you hear a squeak and the light thud of someone sitting next to you. You recognize Ren's voice:
^Well hey there, stranger! I'm so happy you could show up.
^(Prank her) Wait, uh, who are you?

c-2: ^Oh, I'm so-so-so-so sorry! It's Ren. I didn't mean to, er.

RiverHouse205: ^How about starting off with some of my mom's famous cherry pie? It's for us!
RiverHouse206: ^Well, I'm so glad you're here. How were the applications?
^Suddenly, Ren's mom butts into the conversation:
^Hold it! You applied to some places here in town? Well, congratulations and good luck on your job search.
RiverHouse207: ^Hey, I won't say anything to you that I wouldn't say to my own kids,
^. If you're planning on getting a job, and you're really, really serious about it, and I mean really, really, really wanting it, well then you oughta follow-up!
RiverHouse208: ^Well, following up is only the most guaranteed way to make sure you stand out from the crowd. Well, aside from applying.
RiverHouse209: ^All of these places are probably getting tons of applications. Ain't no employer wants to sort through all those. They like having people communicate with them for entry level jobs like these. Makes it easy on them.
^I mean, as long as you're polite that is. Your goal is to score an interview right now. Think about some ways you can do that.
RiverHouse210: ^Well, we got at least one number, right
^? We can always look their numbers up online if we forget or need more.
^You kids know more about that looking up stuff than me. Anyway,
^, I recommend that. 'Nuff said. Now enjoy your pie. It's made with love!

b: ^You take a forkful of cherry pie and bring it to your lips. It's warm, tart, and absolutely delicious. You hear Ren talking with her mouth full:
^, can my mom make a good pie or what?
^It's so cool that your mom bakes treats for you.

c-0: ^Right? Best dessert in town, hands down.
c-1: ^Yeah, I've got a pretty cool mom.
c-2: ^How about you finish the slice that's in front of you first?

b: ^You hear the sound of Ren's fork separating the pie on her plate. A moment later, she says with her mouth full:
^Mmm, oh my gosh, I can't believe how much I missed this.

RiverHouse212: ^It's so great to be back in Lilymist. I thought I'd never be back after my train trip. That was when we met, actually!

c-0: ^Oh, just a few towns over to visit my grandparents for a weekend. I've never been too far away from home.
c-1: ^Yeah, it must be so weird for you. Me, I was just visiting my grandparents a few towns over for a weekend. You, you're in a brand new town for the entire summer.

RiverHouse213: ^Honestly, I love it here. It feels like everyone in Lilymist is part of one big family. I'm not sure what I'd do without that support. I mean, look at all the people who came out just to celebrate me coming back!

c-0: ^I just don't think I could see myself moving somewhere else. Oh, well, unless I could invent a time machine. Then there'd be so many places I'd want to go.
^Exactly! Imagine all the places you could go!
c-2: ^Yeah, I know, I know. It'll never happen. But it would be so cool.

RiverHouse214: ^You can hear the smile in Ren's voice. She says:
^Me? I would go to England in the 1800s. It's kind of silly, but I've loved Victorian Romance novels ever since I was in middle school. The pageantry, the family drama. Ugh, I live for that stuff.
^Not to mention there's tons of spicy romance.

c-0: ^Thanks, but it's okay. Everyone's got their guilty pleasure, and this is mine.
c-1: ^Ah, no way! I knew we had something in common!
c-2: ^I'm not reading it just for the handsome lords and ladies, you know.
^Okay, fine, so I dreamed of being swept off my feet by a charming gentleman until I was in 8th grade. Who hasn't?

RiverHouse215: ^I'm not just interested in Victorian history either. Ancient civilizations, U.S. history.
^Oh, wait! You haven't been to the theater in town, have you? We have to go!
RiverHouse216: ^You hear Ren stand up as she calls out to her mom.
^ and I are going to see if Mr. Crenshaw will give us a tour of the theater, okay?
^Again? Well, all right. Just don't stay out too late, now, you hear?
RiverHouse217: ^Ren turns back to you and says:

^The Barlow Theatre is about as close as it gets to a time machine in Lilymist! It's this old stage building built in Lilymist in the 1920s. You wouldn't believe some of the things they say about the theater's builder.
^"Again"? How many times have you gone on this tour?
^I don't know, I'm not feeling up to it.

c-0: ^It's okay! I already said hi to everyone. I'm sure no one will miss us. Now, what do you say?
c-1: ^This makes four! But the tour guide makes the experience really special. Each time it's like a whole new experience. Now, what do you say?
c-2: ^Aw, are you sure? Any chance I can talk you into it?

b: ^Well, okay. I suppose you've got your job applications to think about anyway. Still, thanks for coming to my party,
^! I'm so glad you got to try our world-famous cherry pie!
^Well, okay. I suppose you've got your job applications to think about anyway. Still, thanks for coming to my party,

RiverHouse219a: ^Have a nice time with Ren, dear! She's right, the theater is marvelous, and I happen to know that Mr. Crenshaw, the tour guide, is great about visually describing everything that's in there. He doesn't miss a detail!
RiverHouse219b: ^You and Aunt Tilly stick around for a little while, enjoying the rest of the party, not to mention the absolutely delicious food made by Ren's mom. A little while later, you both head home.
Theater201: ^You take Ren's elbow and follow her out into the evening street. She's practically vibrating with energy. A few minutes of walking later, she starts to slow down. You hear her exclaim:
^This is it! Ooh, this is so exciting!
Theater202: ^Ren leads you inside, and you hear a kindly, little old voice address you.
^Why, hello there! Who do I have the pleasure of—? Well, well, if it isn't my favorite tour guest.
Theater203: ^, it's a pleasure to meet you. I'm Teddy Crenshaw, your tour guide for this evening here at the remarkable Barlow Theatre. Feel free to call me "Teddy," "Mr. Crenshaw," "Mr. Teddy," it's all the same to me!
^What's the first stop on the tour?

c-0: ^The pleasure's all mine! Now, let's get started.
c-1: ^Eager to see the theater, are we? I certainly don't blame you. Let's get started.
c-2: ^You hear the grin in Teddy's voice.
^A comedian, eh? You would've done well at the Barlow Theatre during its heyday. This theater hosted both vaudeville comedy acts and stage plays back in the 1920s.

Theater204: ^You and Ren follow Teddy through a pair of thick, heavy doors. With pride, Teddy says:
^Welcome to the Barlow Theatre's main stage. Before you is one of the most opulently decorated stages in the region.
Theater205: ^His voice echoing off the theatre's walls, Teddy goes on to describe the space.

^About 50 rows of seats in front of you is the stage. This entire room is decorated with polished brass ornaments and candle sconces, and the walls are lined with portraits of great playwrights, from Shakespeare to Aeschylus.
^Next to you, you can hear Ren bouncing on her feet.
^Yep, you're definitely a history buff, alright.
^Let's just move on with the tour.

c-0: ^That she is. She could practically run this tour herself if she wanted to.
c-2: ^Very well. I can see you're eager to get a taste of the space.

Sam_Barlow: ^Samuel Barlow was the architect who built this theater. A renaissance man, he traveled the world in search of inspiration, then came here to Lilymist to build a theater where his plays could be shown. He was English, hence the reason "Barlow Theatre" is spelled with the "E" after the "R."

c-0: ^All over the world. He was born in 1898 to a pair of farmers in a small town in England, but, being a restless man, he didn't stay there long. In his twenties he traveled all of Europe, from Wales down to Greece, and even ventured as far as Japan. ^Ren interjects: ^Imagine how cool that would be. And he was only 21!
c-1: ^After travelling the world over, he decided that he wanted to be an artist. He tried his hand at a number of different trades, eventually becoming a decent architect, but it was the stage that caught his eye the most.

c-0: ^When he first travelled to America, Broadway was in its heyday, but he dreamed of establishing a chain of big theatres in smaller, rural towns just like the one he'd grown up in back in England. ^Ren speaks up again, her voice sounding wistful. ^Some part of him must've missed home. He wanted to travel the world, but he couldn't just give that up.

c-2: ^Depends on who you ask. His first work, Man Adrift, was a comedy about a sailor who finds himself shipwrecked on an island, where, by sheer coincidence, all of his forgotten schoolfriends, former lovers, and family members have shipwrecked as well. He's forced to reconcile with them as they all wait to be rescued.
^It's a bit of a ridiculous premise.

c-0: ^Indeed. A lot of people compare the protagonist's struggle to avoid all these people in his life with Barlow's own conflicted feelings about leaving his home in England to travel the world.
^Yeah. Imagine leaving your whole life behind like that. His family must've been on  his mind a lot.

^Teddy continues: ^Unfortunately, though, few critics liked Man Adrift, and few production companies were interested in his work. So, being the ambitious man he was, Sam Barlow decided to make his own production company and his own theater in order to put on his plays. Hence, the Barlow Theatre!

Tour_Continues: ^Teddy walks you and Ren up onto the stage, then to another set of doors and says:
^Welcome backstage! This is where all the magic happened, so to speak.

c-0: ^This dressing room still gets a lot of use. Our local young performance troupe, the Barlow Society, puts on shows here every couple of months, and folks come from all over to see our Shakespeare performances in the spring and summer.
^You can practically hear Ren bouncing on her heels.
^? It's like having a slice of history right in your own backyard!
^You really love this stuff, don't you?
^Right? Some of my friends think it's weird to be this into history. It's nice to hang out with somebody who gets it.
c-1: ^Only with my entire heart and soul! Some people think it's werid to be as into history as I am, but what do they know?
c-2: ^Aah, I bet you just haven't had somebody teach it to you in a way that's fun.

Tour_Continues_2: ^When it comes down to it, history is all about stories, and who doesn't love a good story?

c-0: ^After exploring the backstage area, Teddy shows you the front of the building, the theater balcony, the lounge area, and the changing rooms that theater-goers would've used back in the 20s. Ren has something to add about each and every little detail.

Tour_Continues_3: ^Finally, Teddy walks you through the door of a smaller room near the back of the theater.
^And here we have Sam Barlow's office, where he did most of the writing for his plays. We've furnished the room to resemble what it might have been like back in the 1920s.

c-0: ^, there're a ton of great pieces of Art Deco furntirue in here. This dark wooden desk, that old-fasioned wall clock, this little four-legged writing stool, and – oh my gosh – that's a typewriter! Mr. Crenshaw, you didn't tell me you set all this up!
^I thought I'd surprise you with something new. Besides, maybe this could give you some inspiration for that novel you're working on.
^Oh, uh, thanks, Teddy! I mean, I haven't been working on that novel in a while. And besides, it's set in the 1800s, not the Roaring Twenties.
^You're writing a novel? That's so cool!
^It's not a Victorian Romance, is it?
^. It's not really anything serious, though. I haven't even finished the first draft.
^Last you told me it was up to 200 pages. I'd wager you're getting pretty close to your draft!
c-1: ^Oh my gosh, don't make me regret I told you that I read those,
^Never be embarassed about your passion, Ren.

Tour_Over: ^Anyway, I'll let you two admire the room for a little bit. Enjoy, you two, and thanks for visiting the theater!
^Thanks, Mr. Crenshaw, we really appreciate it!

b: ^? It's especially nice to come through here with a fellow history geek. Thanks for doing this with me!
^? I know you might not be a huge history dork like me, but I'm glad you came anyway. It's nice to be able to share this with somebody.

Post_Tour_with_Ren: ^I feel like I learned a lot about you.
^So, tell me about this novel you're writing.

c-0: ^That's great! We should definitely hang out some more when you're able to take a break from the job hunt.
c-1: ^Yeah! What can I say? This girl loves old stuff. That, and stories. The Barlow Theatre has both!
^Anyway, we should definitely hang out some more when you're able to take a break from the job hunt.
c-2: ^Maybe some other time. I'm not sure I'm ready for that kind of embarassment. Tell you what, maybe I'll show you my latest draft next time we hang out.

Leaving_the_Theater: ^You and Ren walk home together, chatting about this-and-that as you go.
Follow_Up_Segment_Start: ^Over the next few days, you continue settling in and exploring the town. The smell of fresh dew on your aunt and uncle's farm, the sound of the waterfall, and the smell of fresh muffins wafting out of the Crumble Café all become familiar to you.

Kai202: ^Suddenly, you hear a voice from outside call out:
Kai203: ^An instant later, you hear a skateboard pull up in front of your house followed by some rapid knocking on the door. You open up and hear Kai, talking fast.
^, hey! you gotta check out what's happening downtown. C'mon!

c-1: ^You'll love it, I promise. Now, let's go!
c-2: ^It'll be fun, I promise! Trust me,
^, you won't want to miss this.

You can't help but wonder what he was talking about. Maybe you could still catch up to him if you ask Aunt Tilly for a ride?
^Catch up with Kai. What the heck, right?

Kai205: ^You follow Kai down the road from your aunt and uncle's house. When you arrive downtown, you hear the sounds of music and laughter all around you. Kai talks to you, unable to hide his excitement:
^Man, it's gonna be a great one this year!
Kai206b: ^Oh, yeah. But relax, this is going to be the most fun kidnapping you've ever experienced in your life.
Kai207: ^It's Lilyfest, the town's big music festival. Everyone gathers out on the big lawn in front of the school to hear all the different local bands play. It's totally rad, check it out!

^As you follow Kai, you begin to pick out the sounds of instruments of all kinds around you. Kai moves carefully forward, moving around people and maneuvering past crowds and people standing in line. He apologizes to a few people:
^Whoops, sorry, don't mind us! Looks like we ran straight through the churro line,
^. There's a lot more food trucks and stuff than there were last year.
^Sure enough, you pick up the tantalizing smell of frying food nearby.

c-0: ^Soon, you and Kai maneuver past the crowds and find a space for yourselves beneath a tree. You lean back against the tree bark, taking in Lilyfest with all of your senses. Kai gives you a little nudge.
^Pretty dope, right? I'd say this is worth me kidnapping you out of the blue. Besides, now you can help me with my master plan!
